title-group.article-title: Gamma spectroscopy study of soil-plant transfer factor characteristics of 40K, 232Th and 226Ra in some crops cultivated in southwestern region of Nigeria

abstract.p: Soil-plant transfer factor (TF) is one of the vital variables employed in assessing plants uptake of radionuclides and their transfer to food chain for predictive ingestion dose and risk evaluation. To further this goal, the TF characteristics of natural 40K, 232Th and 226Ra were thus investigated in some crops (yam, cassava, rice, maize, groundnut, cowpea, okra, pumpkin leaf, banana and pawpaw) cultivated in southwestern part of Nigeria using HPGe gamma spectroscopy. The obtained results of activity concentration (AC) of the radionuclides across all the cultivated soil samples indicated average values that are less than the global average, whereas in the crops, average values of 226Ra and 232Th, were higher than reference values for different crops group. The overall range of the calculated TF of 40K, 232Th and 226Ra across all the crops was 0.05 (in maize and cowpea) to 15.01 (in banana), 0.01 (in pumpkin leaf and groundnut) to 19.80 (in pawpaw), and 0.04 (in cassava) to 21.30 (in cowpea), respectively. Overall arithmetic mean and geometric mean were estimated as 2.66 and 1.60, 1.11 and 0.43, and 1.10 and 0.54 for 40K, 232Th and 226Ra, respectively. TFs mostly correlated negatively with soil radionuclides, while positive correlation was mostly noticeable in the case of crop. Log normal transform of the TFs data indicated a near normal distribution as against the calculated data. The derived results of this study is here presented as a baseline data suggested for possible radiological risk assessment of food chain of the local population.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Natural occurring non-series 40K and series 232Th and 238U radionuclides, referred to as primordial radionuclides of the earth's crust, are the main sources of natural radiation to humans, the others being cosmogenic radionuclides. It is known fact that foodstuffs contain considerable levels of these natural radionuclides [1]. The starting point of these radionuclides into the food chain is their transfer to plants. Radionuclides are transported to plants by means of root uptake from soil and by direct deposition and absorption on aerial parts of plants [2,3]. The former, termed soil-plant transfer, is the leading passage for transmission of radionuclides to plants [4]. Through the rooting system, the radionuclides together with other required micro nutrients are translocated towards different fragments of plant, including eatable portions and subsequently to the human food chains [4].

Food crops and vegetables represent a larger portion of human daily diet. Fraction of radionuclides originating from the natural soil finds their way to human body when food and water are consumed [5,6]. The soil-plant transfer factor (TF) is therefore a vital variable for assessing plants uptake and transfer to food chain for estimating ingestion exposure doses and performing risk assessment [7]. The intake of food crops with high radionuclides concentration can result to dose accumulation in body organs, posing long-term health effects [8,9]. The UNSCEAR [1] has reportedly estimated worldwide annual ingestion dose of 0.29 mSv from food and water intake as a concern to human health.

In general, soil-plant transfer factor (TF), for a given radionuclides on the basis of dry weight of sample, is defined as the ratio of the concentration of the radionuclide in the plant sample to that of the corresponding rooting zone soil sample [10]. For TF value less than 1, it implies strong binding affinity of radionuclide to soil and less bioaccumulation in plants. On the other hand, value above 1 means active uptake and bioaccumulation in plant [11]. Characteristics study of soil-plant TFs started over 60 years ago following the atmospheric nuclear weapons testing conducted within the period of 1950s and 1960s [10]. Since then, TFs of radionuclides such as 232Th, 229Ra, 228Ra, 238U, 210Pb, 40K, 137Cs, 54Mn, 57Co, 88Y, 85Sr, 103Ru, for different plants and species have been widely reported [2,[5], [6], [7],[12], [13], [14], [15], [16], [17], [18]].

Based on information from reported studies, the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) has given a review and compiled an extensive worldwide range of data of soil-plant TFs [10,19]. The data show that TFs vary greatly and it is mostly impacted by factors ranging from soil type and properties, plant species and metabolic features, chemical form of radionuclides and concentrations in the soil, farming conditions as well as climatic and geographical circumstances [5,10,19,20]. The compiled data show that there exist an order of 1–2 scale differences between the local, national and international environments [10,21]. As a result, site specific evaluation of soil-plant TFs is therefore important for thorough appraisal of translocation to food chain and to humans. This is the focus of this study. While the TFs of some radionuclides have been extensively investigated in some countries, studies of radionuclides transfer to common food crops cultivated in Nigeria is very minimal. Therefore, the aim of this study is to evaluate the characteristics soil-plant transfer factors of 40K, 232Th and 226Ra in some food crops cultivated in southwestern region of Nigeria. The expected results of the study will be suggested for radiological assessment of the food chain of the local population. Also, the results can be applied as reference data by researchers for similar studies and by national environmental standards and regulation agencies, and agriculture and food ministries for determining possible variations in environmental radioactivity that may arise from anthropogenic alteration of the human environment.

sec.title: Study location
sec.p:
Southwestern region of Nigeria is one of the six geopolitical zones of the country consisting of six federating states, namely; Ondo, Ekiti, Osun, Oyo, Ogun and Lagos, and lies between longitude 2° 3″ and 6° 00″ East and latitude 6° 2″ and 8° 37″ North. The region has a total landmass area of 77,818 square kilometer and is predominantly dominated by Yoruba speaking tribe. The six southwestern states and their administrative location are represented in Fig. 1. The geological and environmental setting of the region has been fully detailed [22,23].Fig. 1
Southwestern States of Nigeria and their administrative capital.Fig. 1

sec.title: Samples collection and preparation
sec.p: Soil and crops samples consisting of grains (rice and maize), tubers (yam and cassava), vegetables (okro and pumpkin leaf), legumes (groundnut and cowpea) and fruits (banana and pawpaw) were collected directly from farmlands in 30 towns/locations spreading across all the six states of the study region. At least 5 towns from each state were visited which were carefully selected based on their agricultural activities. Sampling took place between the months of September 2019 and January 2020, when it was noted that the crops were matured for harvesting. Five composite samples of the soil and selected crops from same rooting zones were collected from the selected farmlands where the crops were available and matured for harvesting.

To obtain the food crops, harvesting of the crops was done manually across all the examined farmlands. Harvesting of rice was done with a sickle, the ears of the rice were cut to about 20–30 cm above the ground and were left to dry for about two weeks, and separately packaged in polythene bags. The ears of the maize were plucked directly from the stalk of the plant and then kept in a clean polythene bag to avoid contamination. The tubers crops were harvested from the farms by digging and carefully separated from the soil. The legumes crops (groundnut and cowpea), vegetables crops (Okro and pumpkin leaves) were hand-plucked or in some cases with a knife directly from their plants while the fruit crops (banana and pawpaw) were cut directly from their trees using cutlass. All samples were properly and separately packaged in polyethene bags, labeled accordingly with the name of state and crop, and assigned a code to avoid cross contamination and mix up. Samples were taken to laboratory for preparation. Within the rooting zones, the corresponding soil samples were collected from depth 0–30 cm using soil auger. The soil samples collection, preparation, radiation dose and hazard assessment of the farmlands have been reported elsewhere by same authors [24]. In all, 25 samples each of soil and crops were collected from each state of the study region which amounted to a grand total of 300 samples, that is, 150 soil and 150 crops samples. Fig. 2 shows the locations of samples collection.Fig. 2
Sampling locations.Fig. 2

On arriving the laboratory, the crops samples were prepared one after the other following the procedures of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) [25]. The maize, groundnut and cowpea grains were extracted from their buds, cleaned with distilled water and dried under sunlight condition for 10 days. The backs of the yam, cassava, pawpaw and banana were peeled off using kitchen knife where applicable, washed with distilled, chopped into smaller sizes using grater and then dried under sunlight condition for 10 days. The okro and pumpkin leaf samples were cleaned and also dried under sunlight for 10 days. The rice grains were first sun dried for 3 days, then manually dehusk. This was achieved by passing them over an abrasive table-like surface, then transferred to a tray where they were blown to separate the grains from the husk. The obtained grains were washed, left for 2 days to get dried. All samples were thereafter transferred to an oven at 70 °C until no detectable change in weight was noticed [26] and thereafter were grinded and sieved using 2 mm mesh screen to get fine homogenous powder samples. With electronic weighing scale, 200 g of each dried soil and food crop sample was weighed into a 250 ml cylindrical plastic containers with a cap. Before employing the containers, they left overnight in dilute H2SO4 acid and then rinsed twice with distilled water, all these were done to ensure that there were no external sources of contamination of samples [6]. The containers were hermetically sealed to avoid escape of radionuclides, properly labeled and allowed to rest for 30 days to allow for parent-daughter secular equilibrium of radionuclides to be attained [22,27].

sec.title: Gamma counting of samples for 226Ra, 232Th and 40K activity concentration
sec.p: For the gamma spectroscopic counting of the samples, high-purity germanium (HPGe) detector (CANBERRA, USA) was used. This was available at the Environmental Radioactivity Department, Universidade de Coimbra, Portugal. The detector is of low-background p-type having 38% relative efficiency and energy resolution of 2.1 keV traceable to 60Co. A 5 cm thick lead shield placed round the detector was used to reduce the effects of external radiation sources. The detector was coupled to a multichannel analyzer (Multiport, CANBERRA) and an office computer with GENIE-2000 gamma software installed. Energy calibration in the range of 0–5000 keV from certified 137Cs and 60Co gamma sources were used. IAEA reference samples were used for the efficiency calibration. Details of the calibration of the detector has already been captured in our earlier study [24].

Each sample at a time was positioned on the detector allocated space, was made to fit in perfectly then counted for 60, 000 s, ensuring that counting error was reduced to minimum. For background counting, an empty container having the same size was used and the obtained background count was subtracted the sample count to get the net count of each sample. Acquired gamma spectral was analyzed using GENIE-2000 software. Gamma energy peaks of radionuclides progenies as indicated in Table 1 [4,28] were employed to assess the activities of 232Th, 226Ra and 40K in the samples after carrying out Compton corrections. For the activity of 226Ra, this was evaluated from the gamma energies of 609.3, 1120.3 and 1764.5 keV corresponding to 214Bi and 295.2 and 351.9 keV corresponding to 214Pb. For 232Th, gamma energies of 583.1 and 2614.5 keV for 208TI, 911.2 keV for 228 Ac and 238.6 keV for 212Pb were used in the same way. For 40K, its activity was evaluated from its single gamma energy of 1460.8 keV. The activity concentrations (ACs), in Bq/kg, of 226Ra, 232Th and 40K were then estimated from Equ. 1 according to Ref. sec.title: Soil-plant transfer factors (TF)
sec.p: The soil-plant TF is a useful parameter for assessing plants uptake and transfer to food chain for predictive ingestion dose and radiological evaluation. The soil-plant TF is the ratio of the activity concentration of dry plant part to the activity concentration of dry soil. Here, the TFs were calculated using the definition of Equ. 3 [10,11].3TF=RadionuclideACinplant(Bq/kg)RadionuclideACinsoil(Bq/kg)

sec.title: AC of 40K, 226Ra and 232Th in soil
sec.p:
Table 2 gives the summary of the measured AC in Bq/kg of 40K, 232Th and 226Ra in soil and crops samples on a dry-weight basis. Across all the soil samples, the ACs of 40K ranged from 15.27 Bq/kg in pawpaw soil to 972.00 Bq/kg in cowpea with mean value of 143.93 ± 11.67 Bq/kg. For 232Th, the AC varied from 0.66 Bq/kg in maize soil to 336.19 Bq/kg in groundnut soil, having mean of 17.02 ± 2.43 Bq/kg, and for 226Ra the values ranged from 1.32 Bq/kg in yam soil to 123.01 Bq/kg in okra soil with a mean value of 22.92 ± 1.33 Bq/kg. The obtained mean ACs of 40K, 232Th and 226Ra in the soils were below global average values of 420, 45 and 32 Bq/kg, respectively, reported by the United Nations Scientific Committee on the Effect of Atomic Radiation (UNSCEAR) [1]. The mean ACs being reported in this study are in tandem with earlier studies on farm soil from other parts of Nigeria [3,[29], [30], [31], [32], [33]]. However, the ACs of 40K, 226Ra and 232Th measured in soils of Ropp, Bitsichi, Bukuru and Abeokuta [8,[34], [35], [36]] were about a factor of two higher than what is being reported in this current study. Fig. 3, Fig. 4, Fig. 5 show, respectively, the average ACs of 40K, 232Th and 226Ra obtained in the soil and crop samples. From the results, the examined radionuclides were indicated to be well bound to the farm soil components of the study region. The results also revealed a distribution pattern radionuclides that is less likely even in the soil with noticeable variation within and between samples, depending on natural influences of geological locations, soil geochemical properties, plant types and species [26,37]. This observed variation is a typical feature of natural radionuclides in environmental samples [6,38]. Aside the natural influences, the observed variation may also be the effect of amendment of the soil with fertilizers and other agrochemical inputs as well as the farming culture of the region under study [4,6,18,39,40]. It was noted that 40K in all the samples measured higher concentrations than the other radionuclides, an observation attributable to the natural abundance of potassium-40 which has a fixed ratio with the stable potassium [41]. Ajayi [22] noted that the content of 40K in soil of western Nigeria is due to the occurrence of feldspars of potassium found in the region. 40K is ubiquitous in the earth crust, the content of it in farm soil may also, in part, be ascribed to fertilizers as well as manure residues that may have accumulated in the soil following decades of farming activities [24,32]. This claim collaborates with earlier observation made by Isinkaye [42] in mechanized farms located in Ekiti state where higher 40K AC than other radionuclides was reported, which was attributed to incessant intense application of NPK 15:15:15, a potassium-based fertilizer formulation.Fig. 3

Average AC of 226Ra was always higher than that of 232Th, except in soil samples used for groundnut and pumpkin leaf cultivation where average 232Th was higher by 0.39% and 0.24% respectively. The low values of 232Th obtained in some of the soil samples, (e.g 0.66 and 0.96 in maize and pawpaw soil respectively), may be ascribed to the regional geology that characterize the area where the soil samples were obtained. This is in tandem with earlier AC data reported in soil from urban environments of southwestern region of Nigeria [22,23]. As earlier noted, parental rock materials of the soils may be accountable for the higher 226Ra than 232Th. This claim collaborated with earlier geological studies of the southwestern region that show the existence of uranium minerals, such as monazite, zircon, apatite and allanite [[43], [44], [45]].

sec.title: AC of 40K, 226Ra and 232Th in food crops
sec.p: The measured ACs of 40K, 232Th and 226Ra in crops samples on a dry-weight basis are also given in Table 2. In all, the values were ranged from 18.78 to 972.00 Bq/kg, 1.49 to 36.78 Bq/kg and 1.37 to 39.61 Bq/kg for 40K, 232Th and 226Ra, respectively across all the crop samples. As with the soil, noticeable variation also exists within and between samples. The recorded mean (± standard error) AC for yam, cassava, rice, maize, okra, pumpkin leaf, groundnut, cowpea, banana, and pawpaw is 163.16 ± 25.88, 220.71 ± 30.66, 187.55 ± 30.77, 221.23 ± 61.22, 178.25 ± 30.91, 196.15 ± 21.40, 159.77 ± 37.01, 243.37 ± 40.87, 302.88 ± 55.49, and 238.17 ± 57.61 Bq/kg, respectively for 40K; 4.30 ± 0.89, 5.27 ± 1.10, 8.16 ± 2.34, 5.10 ± 1.04, 5.55 ± 1.24, 9.17 ± 2.44, 6.28 ± 1.58, 4.77 ± 0.82, 9.40 ± 2.50, and 6.99 ± 1.86 Bq/kg, respectively for 232Th; and 8.60 ± 0.97, 11.45 ± 2.03, 13.39 ± 2.91, 10.95 ± 1.82, 11.87 ± 2.58, 10.71 ± 2.08, 12.42 ± 2.40, 10.53 ± 1.65, 9.30 ± 0.84, and 12.62 ± 2.34 Bq/kg, respectively for 226Ra. Fig. 3, Fig. 4, Fig. 5 show the comparison of the average ACs measured in soil and crops.

The highest average AC of 40K and 232Th was obtained in banana, while that of 226Ra was in rice. On the opposite, the lowest average AC was found in groundnut for 40K and yam for 232Th and 226Ra. This contrast earlier study [21] where leafy vegetables (choy sum and crown daisy) measured highest AC. The variation of radionuclides in crops are attributed to metabolic characteristics and availability of radionuclides in each crop. Guidotti et al. [46], Alsaffer et al. [26] and Rosa et al. [41] opined that, differences in the activity concentrations between the uranium and thorium series radionuclides depend on their mobility and absorption in soils. With typical 226Ra and 232Th activity concentrations in the order of tens Bq/kg measured in some crops, intake of the food crops can retain and accumulate the radionuclides in the internal systems. With chronic accumulation, internal radiation source can be set up, which in turn can increase the risk of radiation induce injuries and long-term cancers [47].

It can be seen that some soil had higher AC of the radionuclides, but the crops from them did not show high AC of the radionuclides. This observation affirms that radionuclides activities in soil cannot be the only single factor that determines the AC of radionuclides in crops [48]. Similar to the soil, 40K presents highest AC in all the crops followed by 226Ra and 232Th with exception in banana where 232Th had higher AC than 226Ra by 0.01%. The relatively high 40K concentration might also have resulted from probable use of potassium enriched inorganic fertilizers by farmers during cultivation for better outputs [24,49]. Potassium is a micro nutrient element required by plants and humans. It is very essential in plant metabolism, so it is easily absorbed by plant [50]. Furthermore, 40K has high solubility in natural water, therefore, leading to a greater degree of mobility and absorption in comparison with the other radionuclides [10,21,51]. More so, it has been reported that the transportation and absorption of 40K by plants is highly favoured by physico-chemical properties [52]. It is noted that 40K is homogenously distributed in the body through food and water intake, however, homeostatic and metabolic processes control its concentration throughout the body. Therefore, it does not contribute much to internal radiation doses [53,54].

The average ACs of 226Ra and 232Th obtained in the various food crops are higher than reference values of 30 and 0.5 mBq/kg, respectively in root vegetables and fruits; 50 and 15 mBq/kg, respectively in leaf vegetables, and 80 and 3 mBq/kg in grains [1]. The present values show similar range in comparison with other reported literature data [2,4,6,11,17,18,26,39,40]. Average ACs of 40K, 232Th and 226Ra obtained in this study were noticeably higher than literature values of 36.48–68.02 Bq/kg, 1.26–2.98 Bq/kg and 2.33–5.18 Bq/kg, respectively, in vegetables and 49.10–202.75 Bq/kg, 6.92–16.60 Bq/kg and 9.58–17.78 Bq/kg, respectively, in tuber crops from some communities in Delta, Nigeria associated with oil and gas activities [29]. AC range of 207.2 ± 29.8 to 692.9 ± 30.6 Bq/kg in cassava, 206.7 ± 25.4–243.9 ± 32.5 in yam and 142.1 ± 19.2 to 247.9 ± 23.2 in cocoyam for 40K from farmlands fertilizer factory in Onne, River State Nigeria [30] were comparable with this present study. The researchers attributed the measured values to discharge of effluent resulting from the operation of the fertilizer plant [30]. Average AC of 232Th and 226Ra of this current study were noticeably higher than those measured in the Onne farmlands [30]. Also, the mean ACs obtained in cereal and tuber crops of present study are comparably in range with similar study conducted in Sokoto, Kano, Gbada, Ile-Ife, and Ekiti by Arogunjo et al. [55]. In that study, mean AC of 168 Bq/kg, 6.25 Bq/kg and 5.99 Bq/kg for 40K, 238U/226Ra and 232Th, respectively, in cereal crops and 101 Bq/kg, 15.1 Bq/kg, and 7.41 Bq/kg for 40K, 238U/226Ra and 232Th, respectively, in tuber crops were reported [55]. More so, natural radionuclides concentrations in foodstuff (potato, plantain, millet, rice, yam, maize, cassava, cowpea and cocoyam) from Accra metropolitan [56] were similar to this study for 40K but lower in range for 232Th. Jayasinghe et al. [57] reported higher 40K AC with traces of 226Ra and 232Th in local foodstuff cultivated in mining environment of Sri Lanka. AC of 40K in raw and cooked foodstuff were ranged from 41.51 Bq/kg (rice) to 1183.72 Bq/kg (Drumstick). The average AC of 40K in investigated vegetables and fruits was higher than that reported in this study.

sec.title: Soil-plant TFs of 40K, 226Ra and 232Th in food crops
sec.p:
The soil-plant TFs of 40K, 232Th and 226Ra in the examined crops are given in Table 3, which includes the geometric mean (GM) and geometric standard deviation (GSD). The GM and GSD transform the TF values to a log normal form. The calculated TFs across all the crops for 40K ranged from 0.05 (in maize and cowpea) to 15.01 (in banana); for 232Th, the values ranged from 0.01 (in pumpkin leaf and groundnut) to 19.80 (in pawpaw); while for 226Ra, the values were ranged from 0.04 (in cassava) to 21.30 (in cowpea). The GM values were noted to be lower than the AM, while the GSD values were of higher order than the arithmetic SD. The transfer of radionuclides to the crop shows variation, which depends on the crop type, soil type and radionuclides [12]. Fig. 6 shows the GM variation of the transfer factors across the crops. As noticed, while 40K exhibit some variance, especially in okra, pumpkin leaf, cowpea, banana and pawpaw, no much significant change exists in the transfer factor of 232Th and 226Ra across the crops. Notably, both the AM and GM values of 40K were of the order of about 0.5–1.5 higher than those of 232Th and 226Ra across the crops, except in maize where the AM of 40K falls below that of 232Th. The order of magnitude of the transfer factors for 232Th and 226Ra also varies with the crop type. The mean TF of 232Th in rice, maize, okra, groundnut, banana and pawpaw was higher than that of 226Ra, whereas in the other crops (yam, cassava, pumpkin leaf, and cowpea), 226Ra TF was higher. Only in tuber, cereals and fruit crops that same trend was followed. The observation in the yam, casava, pumpkin leaf and cowpea is consisted with earlier report of low 232 Th TF in spinach, tomato, cucumber and brinjal [11]. At 95% confidence level, the TFs of 40K were significantly higher than that of 232Th and 226Ra whereas no significant difference exists between the transfer factors of 232Th and 226Ra. Minimum of about 7 samples, representing 46.67% of the samples in each crop type have 40K transfer factor value above 1, while a maximum of 5 samples in each group have transfer factor above unity for 232Th and 226Ra. All the investigated crops have AM transfer factor above 1 for 40K, whereas only rice, maize and pawpaw have AM value greater than 1 for 232Th; and for 238U only yam, maize, pumpkin leaf, cowpea and pawpaw have TF AM above 1. Specifically, the highest mean transfer factor value of 4.33, 2.51 and 2.38 for 40K, 232Th and 226Ra, respectively, was found in banana, maize and cowpea, respectively. TFs greater than 1 for 40K (in range of 8.3–78.1 with mean of 42.2) have also been reported in some food crops grown in city of Ho Chi Minh, Vietnam [58]. Higher 40K TF is used to imply plant survival strategy to subdue any serious environmental incidents [58,59]. Table 4 presents a comparison of the transfer factors calculated in this present study with the those from other countries worldwide. The present TF values of 40K, 232Th and 226Ra in the examined crops are quite elevated compared to some reported literature data [29]. The present study is in tandem with that of Karunakara et al. [2] who had reported TFs above 1 for 40K in all examined samples of rice plant parts with mean values of 1.5, 2.0 and 4.9 for soil–grain, soil–root and soil–straw, respectively. Soil–plant transfer factor of 226Ra, 232Th and 40K in cabbage, cucumber, spinach, tomato, brinjal, and tapioca from some parts of Malaysia has also been investigated, with that of 40K ranging from 0.74 to 38.17 [11]. Also, 40K transfer factors in the range of 0.44–107.76 with AM of 26.58 were also reported in Amaranthus hybridus cultivated in different parts of southwestern region of Nigeria [60]. What the present TF values imply, in effect, is that 232Th and 226Ra in soil of the study region and with regards to the examined crops have low absorption and translocation from the soil to various plant fragments. The reason for higher TF of 40K can be attributed to the essential micronutrient requirement of potassium by plant. Also, being more soluble and mobile in soil than thorium and uranium, its absorption by the plant is expected to increase [61,62]. The translocation of the radionuclides to different fragments of plant is also hinged on the metabolic activities underpinning the plant growth [2,17]. The present TF values affirm the dependency of radionuclides uptake by plant on their concentrations in the cultivated soil [10,63].Table 4

The practice of farmers to supplement soil nutrients through the use of manures, fertilizers, and sometimes untreated waste water are anthropogenic pathways of radionuclides enrichment of cultivated soil. With these practices, it is likely for plant to have increase uptake of radionuclides, which implies bioaccumulation in edible parts [11]. Our earlier report on assessment of radionuclides for radiation dose estimation in agricultural soils of southwestern region of Nigeria had indicated possible enrichment of radionuclides, especially 40K, owing to residues of fertilizers incessantly applied over preceding farming seasons by farmers [24]. This also collaborate with earlier research works carried out by Isinkaye [42] and Adedokun et al. [72] in farmland soil from part of Ekiti and Lagos states, respectively, which are part of the southwestern Nigeria. With TFs greater than 1 in some of the crops cultivated in this region, the prediction is possible bioaccumulation in edible parts [11]. Thus, the current data is suggested for radiological assessment of food crops of the local population of the region.

The relationship between the transfer factors and the radionuclides ACs in soil and all crops were analyzed using Pearson correlation analyses, and the correlation coefficients have been tabulated (Table 5). The correlation was done separately for each crop type with their corresponding transfer factors. Correlation coefficients between ±0.5 were considered insignificant. Only the highlighted values in Table 5 were significant at either 0.01 or 0.05 level. Noticeably, the radionuclides transfer factors mostly correlated negatively with the soil radionuclides ACs, whereas the correlation between the TFs and the crops ACs were positively correlated. This observation implies that the radionuclides activity in the crops were directly related to that of the soil. As the radionuclides levels decrease in the soil due to absorption by plant, their ACs in the plant increase though not in a proportionate manner. This observation is presented in scattered plots shown in Fig. 7, Fig. 8, Fig. 9, Fig. 10, Fig. 11 for tuber (yam and cassava), cereals (rice and maize), vegetables (okra and pumpkin leave), legumes (groundnut and cowpea) and fruits (banana and pawpaw) crops, respectively. The scattered plots fitted with log transformed regression trendlines show negative trend between the TF and the soil AC and positive trend between the TF and the crop AC. This negative correlation and trend noticed in the soil might be that the soil physicochemical properties such as soil pH, organic matter content, soil texture, and electrical conductivity which are paramount factors of soil–plant transfer of radionuclides are within narrow bands in soil of the study region. Negative correlation coefficients between soil physicochemical properties and radionuclides transfer factors have been observed for rice plant [2,26], which denotes a reverse relationship. For instance, soil pH level influences adsorption of cations onto soil which decreases with low pH, so hydrogen ion replaced adsorbed cations [17,26].Table 5

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Natural radionuclide (40K, 232Th and 226Ra) concentrations in soil and crops and their TF characteristics in food crops cultivated in southwestern part of Nigeria have been investigated using gamma-ray spectroscopy. At least, two crops from the groups, tuber (yam and casava), cereals (rice and maize), vegetables (okra and pumpkin leaf) legumes (groundnut and cowpea) and fruits (banana and pawpaw) with fifteen replica samples for each soil and crops, making a total of 300 hundred samples were examined. The overall average activity concentrations of 40K, 232Th and 226Ra across all samples were 143.95 Bq/kg (ranged 15.27–972.00 Bq/kg), 17.02 Bq/kg (ranged 0.66–336.19 Bq/kg) and 22.92 Bq/kg (ranged 1.32–123.01 Bq/kg) respectively for soil and 211.12 Bq/kg (ranged 18.78–972.00 Bq/kg), 6.50 Bq/kg (ranged 1.49–36.78 Bq/kg) and 11.18 Bq/kg (ranged 1.37–39.61 Bq/kg) respectively for crops. The average radionuclides concentrations were below global average values of 420, 45 and 32 Bq/kg, respectively for soil [1] whereas for the crops, 226Ra and 232Th were above UNSCEAR reference values of 30 and 0.5 mBq/kg, respectively in root vegetables and fruits; 50 and 15 mBq/kg, respectively in leaf vegetables, and 80 and 3 mBq/kg in grains.

The radionuclides uptake through soil-plant transfer factor was calculated. The calculated TFs across all the crops ranged from 0.05 to 15.01 for 40K, 0.01 to 19.80 for 232Th and 0.04 to 21.30 for 226Ra. Judging on the basis of the calculated TFs, the study has been able to prove that 40K is the most translocated radionuclides from the soil to the examined crops than 232Th and 226Ra. The log normal transform of the data shows that the transfer factors were near normal distribution. Since TF is a vital parameter for radionuclides translocation to food chains, the TFs of this present study is therefore suggested for possible radiological assessment of the food chain of the local population.
